pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 285]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 286, 539, 317]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 115, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>+</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 354, 601, 369]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 369, 907, 400]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 400, 578, 415]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 416, 277, 430]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 431, 868, 461]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 462, 327, 476]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 477, 364, 492]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 493, 329, 507]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 508, 670, 523]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 550, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 566, 570, 615]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40. Each correct answer will score one mark. Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 774, 89]]<|/det|> A wire is approximately \(48 \text{cm}\) long and has an approximate diameter of \(0.3 \text{mm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|> Which measuring instruments can be used to obtain more precise values of the dimensions of the wire? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 146, 581, 275]]<|/det|>
length of the wirediameter of the wire
A30 cm rulermicrometer
Bhalf-metre rule30 cm rule
Chalf-metre rulemicrometer
Dmicrometerhalf-metre rule
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 301, 97, 320]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 301, 472, 320]]<|/det|> The velocity–time graph for a car is shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 329, 737, 555]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 568, 515, 586]]<|/det|> What is the distance travelled by the car in 35 s? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 597, 133, 615]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 597, 205, 615]]<|/det|> 250 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 597, 300, 615]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 597, 373, 615]]<|/det|> 350 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 597, 467, 615]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 597, 539, 615]]<|/det|> 450 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 597, 636, 615]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 597, 707, 615]]<|/det|> 700 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 642, 92, 660]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 642, 799, 660]]<|/det|> Which property of a body results from the effect of a gravitational field on its mass? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 670, 133, 688]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 670, 562, 688]]<|/det|> the ability of the body to resist a change in motion <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 696, 133, 714]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 696, 344, 714]]<|/det|> the density of the body <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 723, 133, 742]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 723, 344, 742]]<|/det|> the volume of the body <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 750, 133, 768]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 750, 336, 768]]<|/det|> the weight of the body

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 528, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
A metal rod of length \(80 \text{cm}\) is pivoted at point O. Its centre of mass is at its mid-point. Four pulley wheels are indicated by the letter P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> The diagram shows an object moving at a constant speed in a circular path in the direction shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 117, 571, 135]]<|/det|> A force acts on the object to keep it in the circular path. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 147, 836, 165]]<|/det|> In which labelled direction does this force act, when the object is in the position shown? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 173, 720, 361]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 384, 94, 403]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 384, 920, 418]]<|/det|> A force \(F\) acts on a body of mass \(m\) for a time \(t\). During this time, the velocity of the body increases from \(u\) to \(v\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 429, 450, 448]]<|/det|> Which equation relates \(F, m, t, u\) and \(v\)? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 459, 131, 477]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 459, 262, 477]]<|/det|> \(Fm = t(v - u)\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 485, 131, 504]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 485, 262, 504]]<|/det|> \(Fm = t(v + u)\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 510, 131, 529]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 510, 262, 529]]<|/det|> \(Ft = m(v - u)\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 536, 131, 555]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 536, 262, 555]]<|/det|> \(Ft = m(v + u)\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 580, 96, 599]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 580, 470, 599]]<|/det|> An object falls towards the Earth's surface. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 611, 856, 630]]<|/det|> What happens to the gravitational potential energy and to the kinetic energy of the object? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 641, 576, 786]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential energykinetic energy
Adecreasesdecreases
Bdecreasesincreases
Cincreasesdecreases
Dincreasesincreases

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 692, 89]]<|/det|> A skier is pulled up a short straight slope at constant speed by a rope. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 100, 641, 250]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 259, 920, 293]]<|/det|> The tension in the rope is \(100 \text{N}\) and there is a combined frictional and air resistance force of \(20 \text{N}\) acting on the skier. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 591, 322]]<|/det|> The slope is \(10 \text{m}\) long and the skier rises \(1.5 \text{m}\) vertically. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 333, 665, 352]]<|/det|> How much work is done by the rope pulling the skier up the slope? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 361, 133, 380]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 361, 198, 380]]<|/det|> 120 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 361, 298, 380]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 361, 368, 380]]<|/det|> 150 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 361, 468, 380]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 361, 544, 380]]<|/det|> 1000 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 361, 636, 380]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 361, 710, 380]]<|/det|> 1200 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 408, 106, 426]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 408, 430, 426]]<|/det|> In some situations, a force does work. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 437, 720, 456]]<|/det|> Which set of conditions increases the quantity of work done by the force? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 466, 529, 612]]<|/det|>
magnitude
of force		distance moved
by the force
Adecreasesdecreases
Bdecreasesstays the same
Cincreasesincreases
Dstays the samedecreases
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 640, 106, 657]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 640, 767, 657]]<|/det|> A measuring cylinder of cross-sectional area \(4.0 \text{cm}^2\) contains \(224 \text{cm}^3\) of liquid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 669, 870, 687]]<|/det|> The pressure of the liquid at the base of the measuring cylinder due to the liquid is \(8800 \text{Pa}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 700, 386, 717]]<|/det|> What is the density of the liquid? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 727, 134, 745]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 727, 245, 745]]<|/det|> 224 kg/ m³ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 727, 303, 745]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 727, 410, 745]]<|/det|> 385 kg/ m³ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 727, 470, 745]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 727, 588, 745]]<|/det|> 1600 kg/ m³ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 727, 636, 745]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[643, 727, 755, 745]]<|/det|> 2200 kg/ m³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
An ice cube of mass \(12 \text{g}\) at \(0^\circ \text{C}\) absorbs thermal energy from the surroundings at a rate of \(3 \text{J / s}\). The specific latent heat of fusion of ice is \(330 \text{J / g}\).

current in \(\mathsf{R}_{1}\)current in \(\mathsf{R}_{2}\)
A\(\mathrm{I}_{1} = \mathrm{I}_{0}\)\(\mathrm{I}_{2} < \mathrm{I}_{0}\)
B\(\mathrm{I}_{1} = \mathrm{I}_{0}\)\(\mathrm{I}_{2} = \mathrm{I}_{0}\)
C\(\mathrm{I}_{1} > \mathrm{I}_{0}\)\(\mathrm{I}_{2} = \mathrm{I}_{0}\)
D\(\mathrm{I}_{1} > \mathrm{I}_{0}\)\(\mathrm{I}_{2} < \mathrm{I}_{0}\)

A very small proportion of the \(\alpha \)-particles are deflected through large angles. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 426, 425, 444]]<|/det|> What does this provide evidence for? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 456, 134, 475]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 456, 368, 475]]<|/det|> \(\alpha \)-particles are very small. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 483, 131, 501]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 483, 505, 501]]<|/det|> There are negative electrons in each atom. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 508, 131, 526]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 508, 455, 526]]<|/det|> There is a tiny nucleus in each atom. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 535, 133, 553]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 535, 430, 552]]<|/det|> There are neutrons in each atom. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 580, 107, 598]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 580, 606, 598]]<|/det|> The table compares \(\alpha \)-radiation, \(\beta \)-radiation and \(\gamma \)-radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 610, 297, 628]]<|/det|> Which row is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 640, 927, 766]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\)-radiation\(\beta\)-radiation\(\gamma\)-radiation
Amore ionising than \(\beta\) or \(\gamma\)a protonelectromagnetic radiation
Bless ionising than \(\beta\) or \(\gamma\)an electrontwo protons and two neutrons
Cmore ionising than \(\beta\) or \(\gamma\)an electronelectromagnetic radiation
Dless ionising than \(\beta\) or \(\gamma\)electromagnetic radiationa proton

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 769, 89]]<|/det|> A high-voltage power supply is connected to a metal grid and a wire, as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[269, 98, 725, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 269, 920, 303]]<|/det|> When the radioactive source is placed close to the grid, sparks are observed in the position indicated. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 316, 566, 333]]<|/det|> Which statement explains why the sparks are formed? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 344, 134, 361]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 344, 400, 361]]<|/det|> \(\alpha \cdot\) particles have a long range. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 371, 133, 388]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 371, 379, 388]]<|/det|> \(\alpha \cdot\) particles have no charge. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 397, 133, 415]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 397, 368, 415]]<|/det|> \(\alpha \cdot\) particles have no mass. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 425, 133, 444]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 425, 416, 444]]<|/det|> \(\alpha \cdot\) particles are strongly ionising. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 470, 104, 488]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 470, 920, 504]]<|/det|> A student investigates four different radioactive isotopes. The student places a detector near each radioactive material. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 515, 776, 533]]<|/det|> The background count rate is 36 counts per minute throughout the investigation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 545, 675, 562]]<|/det|> The table shows the detector readings at the start and after 8 hours. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 575, 450, 593]]<|/det|> Which isotope has a half-life of 4 hours? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 604, 628, 750]]<|/det|>
